Graphical abstract A redox-active covalent organic framework (RaCOF) is designed as a barrier-trapping electrocatalyst for enhancing the temperature adaptability of Li–S batteries, leading to improved sulfur redox reactions and stable operation from −10 to +60 °C. Covalent organic frameworks (COFs) are promising materials for mitigating polysulfide shuttling in lithium-sulfur (Li–S) batteries, but enhancing their ability to convert polysulfides across a wide temperature range remains a challenge. Herein, we introduce a redox-active COF (RaCOF) that functions as both a physical barrier and a kinetic enhancer to improve the temperature adaptability of Li–S batteries. The RaCOF constructed from redox-active anthraquinone units accelerates polysulfide conversion kinetics through reversible C=O/C-OLi transformations within a voltage range of 1.7 to 2.8 V (vs. Li+/Li), optimizing sulfur redox reactions in ether-based electrolytes. Unlike conventional COFs, RaCOF provides bidentate trapping of polysulfides, increasing binding energy and facilitating more effective polysulfide management. In-situ XRD and ToF-SIMS analyses confirm that RaCOF enhances polysulfide adsorption and promotes the transformation of lithium sulfide (Li2S), leading to better sulfur cathode reutilization. Consequently, RaCOF-modified Li–S batteries demonstrate low self-discharge (4.0% decay over a 7-day rest), excellent wide-temperature performance (stable from −10 to + 60 °C), and high-rate cycling stability (94% capacity retention over 500 cycles at 5.0 C). This work offers valuable insights for designing COF structures aimed at achieving temperature-adaptive performance in rechargeable batteries. Keywords Lithium-sulfur batteries Redox-active property Covalent organic framework Wide-temperature adaptability 1 Introduction The efficient utilization of renewable energy has become a critical area of research and development, especially in addressing the intermittent power supply issues associated with clean energy sources like solar, wind, and tidal energy [1–4]. High-energy–density rechargeable batteries present a promising solution to these challenges [5–11]. Among various battery technologies, lithium-sulfur (Li–S) batteries stand out due to their high theoretical energy density (2600 Wh kg−1) and the abundance of sulfur resources [12–16]. Despite these advantages, the practical application of Li–S batteries is significantly limited by several factors, including the shuttling of lithium polysulfides, slow sulfur reaction kinetics, lithium dendrite formation, and severe self-discharge behavior [17–23]. Additionally, large-scale outdoor energy storage systems are often exposed to rapid changes in regional climate and environmental temperatures. Under such conditions, Li–S batteries suffer from even slower reaction kinetics at low temperatures and increased polysulfide shuttling at high temperatures, making their adoption under wide temperature conditions particularly challenging [24–27]. To address the persistent challenges in Li–S batteries, researchers have developed numerous modification strategies, such as advanced sulfur cathodes [28], metal-based electrocatalysts [9,29], electrolyte modulation [30,31], and novel organosulfur cathodes [32,33]. While these approaches have improved the electrochemical performance of Li–S batteries at room temperature [34–37], their effectiveness under extreme temperature conditions remains limited. This limitation is primarily due to accelerated polysulfide shuttle kinetics at high temperatures and increased energy barriers for polysulfide conversion at low temperatures, reducing sulfur cathode utilization and cycling stability. Metal-based electrocatalysts have been used to trap and catalyze polysulfides over a wide temperature range [38–40]. However, they often form strong metal-sulfur bonds with high binding energy (over 2.0 eV), which can weaken internal Li–S bonds, leading to Li2Sx species decomposition [38,41]. Additionally, metal-based catalysts can suffer from reduced catalytic efficiency due to the accumulation of sulfates on their surface after prolonged cycling, diminishing their effectiveness [24,42]. Furthermore, the incorporation of metal-based electrocatalysts often requires high carbon content and increases battery density, which detracts from the inherent advantages of Li-S batteries. Covalent organic framework (COF) materials have attracted significant interest for use in rechargeable batteries due to their lightweight nature, tunable structures, and specific functionalities [43–46]. In Li-S batteries, COFs can mitigate polysulfide dissolution and shuttling and improve cycling stability through physical blocking and chemical adsorption within their frameworks [47–50]. Some studies have demonstrated enhanced electrochemical performance using COF/sulfur composite cathodes through covalent interactions with sulfur species [51–53]. However, these cathodes often perform poorly at low temperatures due to the inherently low electronic conductivity of COFs. Alternatively, COF-modified separators can indirectly block polysulfide shuttling that requiring minimal electronic conductivity have garnered significant interest [45,54–56]. Nevertheless, relying solely on the physical blocking and noncovalent adsorption provided by COFs on the separator surface is inadequate to propel the kinetics of polysulfide conversion, leading to only limited performance improvements across a broad temperature range. Redox mediators (e.g., metallocene, anthraquinone derivatives, and selenium/tellurium-based mediators) have been used to catalyze polysulfide conversion and promote a homogeneous redox reaction in sulfur cathodes [57–60]. Unfortunately, most redox mediators are soluble in the electrolyte, potentially worsening polysulfide shuttling and leading to the depletion of both the mediator and active material [59,60]. Given the chemical stability and precise designability of COFs, designing COFs with implanted redox mediators may hold promise for enhancing the performance of Li-S batteries with better temperature adaptability. However, the development of redox-active COFs for wide-temperature adaptability in Li-S batteries remains largely unexplored. Herein, we developed a quinone-based COF (denoted RaCOF) with an ordered porous structure and built-in redox-active trapping sites, serving as an electrocatalyst for trapping and catalyzing polysulfides over a wide temperature range. In-situ attenuated total reflectance Fourier-transform infrared (ATR-FTIR) measurements demonstrated the reversible transformation of C=O/C-OLi reaction in RaCOF within the full voltage range of Li–S batteries. Combining in-situ XRD, ToF-SIMS, and theoretical calculations, it verified that RaCOF can accelerate the adsorption of polysulfides and enhance the generation process of terminal lithium sulfide (Li2S) and the reutilization of sulfur cathode. By employing a separator modification strategy, we successfully achieved wide-temperature (operation from −10 to + 60 °C), low-self-discharge (4.0% decay rate over a 7-day rest), high-rate (94% retention over 500 cycles at 5.0 C) Li–S batteries through the synergistic effect of RaCOF’s unique structure, which includes porosity, adsorption, and catalytic properties. This work elucidates the catalytic mechanisms of functional COFs and provides insights into the rational design of COF structures for applications in wide-temperature batteries. 2 Results and discussion 2.1 Molecular design and characterization of redox-active COF To explore the role of the redox-active groups within COF structures, we designed and synthesized RaCOF, which contains quinone groups, and its counterpart PhCOF, which lacks quinone groups. Both RaCOF and PhCOF were synthesized using a Schiff-base solvothermal reaction with tunable building blocks (Scheme 1 ). Detailed synthesis procedures are provided in the Supporting Information. After synthesizing the COF materials, we applied the designed COFs to coat commercial separators for trapping and catalyzing lithium polysulfides (LiPSs) (Fig. 1 a). As shown in Fig. 1b, the synthesized COFs were first subjected to the powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) tests. Both RaCOF and PhCOF displayed two characteristic peaks at 3.15° and 26.56°, corresponding to the (100) and (001) facets, respectively, which is aligned with the AA-eclipsed and π-π stacking models [61]. The intense peak for the (100) facet indicates that AA-eclipsed stacking predominates in the main COF structures, providing abundant ordered channels for Li+ migration. Subsequently, the X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) survey reveals that both COFs primarily contain carbon, nitrogen, and oxygen atoms (Figure S1). In addition to the C=C and C–N sub-peaks, the C=O peak was observed at 288.3 eV for RaCOF and 288.5 eV for PhCOF (Fig. 1c). Notably, the integral area of the C=O sub-peak for RaCOF (18.3%) is higher than that of PhCOF (14.1%) (Fig. 1d), indicating the additional introduction of quinone units. Thermogravimetric analyses demonstrated that RaCOF exhibits better thermal stability compared to PhCOF (Figure S2). Additionally, the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) surface area test showed that RaCOF and PhCOF have similar surface areas of 295 and 309 m2 g−1, respectively (Fig. 1e), and similar pore size distributions (Figure S3). It was revealed that both RaCOF and PhCOF possess fluffy and porous morphologies (Figures S4 and S5). To study the intrinsic redox-active properties of the COF materials, Li//COF half-cells were assembled and tested with 80 wt% COF cathode materials (containing 10 wt% carbon additive and 10 wt% PVDF binder). The RaCOF-based cell exhibits an initial capacity of 118 mAh g−1, which decreases to 67 mAh g−1 and maintains at 47 mAh g−1 at 100th cycles (Fig. 1f). In contrast, the PhCOF-based half-cell initially delivers 33 mAh g−1 (Figure S6), decreasing to 16 mAh g−1 and stabilizing at 2.6 mAh g−1, indicating that PhCOF lacks redox-active properties. After that, in-situ ATR-FTIR was conducted to study the structure transformations under simultaneous electrochemical testing conditions [62]. Paired with cyclic voltammetry (CV) testing, the 2D contour map for real-time ATR-FTIR spectra was collected and displayed in Fig. 1g. To clearly distinguish the spectral changes, the spectrum obtained at open-circuit voltage was used as the background reference. In the contour map, the characteristic absorbance peaks at 1230, 1300, 1430, and 1620–1650 cm−1 correspond to C–C, C–O, C=C, and C=O bands, respectively. As the discharge process (reduction process) proceeds, the C–O and C=C bonds gradually strengthen, while the C–C and C=O bonds gradually decrease. This result indicates that the carbonyl group in the anthraquinone group in the RaCOF material undergoes Li+ complexation behavior (Figure S7). During the charging process (oxidation process), the above characteristic peaks gradually weaken and disappear, indicating a reversible redox reaction of the RaCOF material. Notably, two distinct characteristic peaks appeared at 1005 and 1046 cm−1, attributing to the antisymmetric stretching vibrations of ether C–O–C bond (e.g., DME), and a peak at 902 cm−1 attributing to the symmetric stretching vibration peaks of cyclic ether (e.g., DOL). The characteristic peaks of ethers align with the redox trend of RaCOF materials, indicating that RaCOF reversibly stores solvated lithium ions. In contrast, the contour map of the PhCOF sample showed only solvated lithium-ion storage behavior with a certain degree of irreversibility (Figure S8). This suggests that PhCOF, lacking redox activity, can only adsorb a small amount of lithium ions through its porous structure. 2.2 Polysulfide conversion and catalytic performance analysis Subsequently, a COF-modified separator was fabricated by casting the composited slurry of COF materials, carbon black, and PVDF binder on Celgard 2500. Initially, the COF-modified separators feature uniform coating thickness of 10 μm (Figure S9) and show decreased contact angle towards the electrolyte (Figure S10), which may enhance the physical contact between the separator and cathode, thereby reducing ion migration impedance (Figure S11) and enhancing ionic conductivity (Figure S12). To study the electrocatalytic performance of COFs in facilitating polysulfide conversion, a symmetric cell composed of two COF-based electrodes paired with sandwiching Li2S6 electrolytes was assembled and investigated. Based on the CV test, the symmetric cell without COF material shows negligible current density (Fig. 2 a). In contrast, the COF-modified symmetric cells exhibited higher current response, with the RaCOF-based cell showing a more prominent current density than the PhCOF-based cell. This indicates an enhanced catalytic kinetics for the conversion of LiPSs in the RaCOF-based cell. Moreover, the the Li//COF-modified separator//Al foil cell without any sulfur-based materials was directly evaluated to assess its electrochemical activity. The RaCOF cell shows a higher current response than PhCOF, with a minor reduction peak at 2.0 V and a broad oxidation peak between 2.1 and 2.4 V, likely reflecting the redox activity of anthraquinone units (Figure S13). In contrast, PhCOF exhibits a smaller current response of approximately 0.02 mA cm−2, possibly due to pore adsorption of solvated ions. Additionally, the RaCOF cell maintained stable cycling and sustained capacity even without a sulfur cathode (Figure S14), indicate that RaCOF undergoes a reversible redox reaction and maintains electrochemical activity over a long period. A potentiostatic discharging test for Li2S precipitation was further conducted using a Li//COF two-compartment cell [19]. In this setup, the catholyte consisted of 0.5 M Li2S8 in DOL/DME (v/v, 1/1), serving as the cathode. The nucleation peak for the Li//PhCOF appears at 453 s with a nucleation capacity of 189.6 mAh g−1 (Fig. 2b). In contrast, the nucleation peak for the Li//RaCOF cell appears earlier (301 s) with a larger nucleation capacity of 215.1 mAh g−1 (Fig. 2c), indicating the enhanced catalytic efficiency of RaCOF in converting liquid polysulfides to terminal Li2S/Li2S2. Additionally, the current–time transient profiles with quantitative peak fitting were performed to study the kinetics of Li2S deposition [63]. There are four classical models of electrochemical deposition, namely, 2D progressive (2DP), 2D instantaneous (2DI), 3D progressive (3DP), and 3D instantaneous (3DI) nucleation model [64]. In traditional ether-based solvents, the low solubility of Li2S dictates its growth mode. Specifically, the deposition of Li2S in ether-based electrolytes is controlled by the surface diffusion of adatoms, following a 2D growth pattern. This mode can cause early termination of the deposition process because of the rapid passivation of the electrode surface. As shown in Fig. 2b, the Li2S nucleation mode for the PhCOF-based separator inclined towards the 3DP model, suggesting an enhanced nucleation rate with more achievable Li2S deposition (inset in Fig. 2b). Furthermore, when using the RaCOF-modified cell, the Li2S nucleation shifted to a 3D growth mode (inset in Fig. 2c), indicating a faster nucleation rate facilitated by the redox-active COF mediator. To further investigate the molecular tunning effect, DFT calculations were conducted (Fig. 2d). Compared to PhCOF, the introduction of anthraquinone unit in RaCOF results in a decreased LUMO energy and an overall bandgap reduction from 2.53 eV to 1.95 eV. The narrowed bandgap indicates enhanced conductivity of the semiconducting organic frameworks [65]. Subsequently, the binding behavior between COF monomers and LiPSs was analyzed. As shown in Fig. 2e, the PhCOF/Li2S6 monomer exhibits a binding configuration between the ketone carbonyl and the terminal lithium site of Li2S6, demonstrating monodentate trapping behavior. In contrast, the RaCOF/Li2S6 monomer displays a bidentate binding configuration involving both the ketone carbonyl and the anthraquinone unit, indicating synergistic trapping behavior. Accordingly, RaCOF shows increased binding energy for intercepting polysulfides, with specific binding energy values of 1.6, 1.8, and 1.3 eV for Li2S8, Li2S6, and Li2S4, respectively (Fig. 2f). The polysulfide (i.e., Li2S6) adsorption experiment and the corresponding UV–vis spectroscopy further illustrated the trapping ability for COFs (Figure S15). Hence, RaCOF’s excellent catalytic performance primarily stems from its strong polysulfide adsorption capability. Combined with its intrinsic semiconductor properties and the added conductive carbon, RaCOF enables the intercepted polysulfides to rapidly gain or lose electrons, facilitating efficient catalytic conversion of polysulfides. Moreover, the dynamic reaction activation energies of the COF monomers toward various polysulfide species were calculated. Fig. 2g depicts the relative free energy landscape from S8 to Li2S during the discharge process, along with the optimized interaction configurations shown in the insets. Specifically, the RaCOF sample shows a relative lower energy level compared of PhCOF, indicating a more thermodynamically favorable process for RaCOF. The free energy from the conversion S8 to Li2S8 was calculated to be −3.81 eV on the RaCOF surface, which is more exothermic than that of PhCOF (−3.07 eV). Furthermore, both RaCOF and PhCOF exhibited significant energy variations during the final steps from Li2S4 to Li2S2 and then to Li2S, suggesting that the formation of the terminal discharge products (e.g., Li2S2 and Li2S) is challenging. These last two reduction steps are reported to be the rate- and capacity-limiting steps in Li–S batteries [7,19]. During the initial oxidation process, Li2S first undergoes delithiation. Calculating the decomposition energy barrier of Li2S allows for an analysis of the difficulty of the oxidation reaction. The delithiation energy barriers of Li2S on PhCOF and RaCOF are calculated to be 2.14 and 1.58 eV, respectively (Fig. 2h). Collectively, these results demonstrate that the active quinone moiety in RaCOF can bidirectionally promote the phase transformation of Li2S, thereby improving battery performance. 2.3 Mechanism analysis of polysulfide evolution and conversion To deeply detect the impact of the COFs on converting polysulfides, the interfacial composition and sulfur species were characterized by ToF-SIMS after 10 repeated cycles at a current density of 0.2 C and collected at the discharged state. ToF-SIMS characterization was conducted in an anionic mode to detect all sulfur-containing anions, including LiS−, LiS2 −, LiS4 −, LiS6 −, and LiS8 − species. Specifically, the three-dimensional (3D) distributions of various sulfur anion species within the RaCOF coating layer are shown in Fig. 3 a, revealing dense distributions of LiS− and LiS2 −, indicative of the high yields of terminal discharged products such as Li2S and Li2S2. The ToF-SIMS analysis of RaCOF shows relatively low concentrations of long-chain lithium polysulfides, especially LiS4 − and LiS8 −, which are indexed to Li2S4 and Li2S8 products (mapping image shown in Figure S16). This result indicates that long-chain polysulfides were largely reduced to terminal solid products of Li2S and Li2S2. In contrast, Fig. 3b shows the 3D distributions of sulfur species for the PhCOF counterpart. The long-chain polysulfide-derived anions, including LiS4 −, LiS6 −, and LiS8 −, are more concentrated than in RaCOF (Figure S17). This implies that the soluble polysulfides of Li2S4, Li2S6, and Li2S8 are still trapped within the PhCOF coating layer, leading to inferior secondary utilization. The detailed intensity plots over sputter time were depicted to quantify the differences between RaCOF and PhCOF. As shown in Fig. 3c, the stable counts for the LiS−, LiS2 −, LiS4 −, LiS6 −, and LiS8 − anions in the RaCOF sample are 5350, 730, 31, 84, and 7, respectively. This indicates a large proportion of terminal discharge product Li2S (86.3%). In contrast, the stable counts for the PhCOF sample are 3120, 350, 560, 214, and 115 for the LiS−, LiS2 −, LiS4 −, LiS6 −, and LiS8 − anions, respectively, indicating an inferior yield percentage for terminal discharge product Li2S (71.6%) (Fig. 3d). The high percentage of remaining Li2S4 (12.8%) suggests a lower utilization rate of soluble lithium polysulfides (Figure S18). These results demonstrate that RaCOF can significantly enhance the conversion of long-chain polysulfides to the terminal discharge product Li2S compared to the inactive PhCOF counterpart. Furthermore, the chemical compositions on the surface of the RaCOF coating layer were analyzed using XPS. It should be noted that the COF coating layer may be covered by dense sulfate after long-term cycling, making it difficult to probe COF structural variations. To accurately detect the RaCOF structure, we collected the initially discharged and charged cells and disassembled them in an Ar-filled glove box during the entire testing procedure. As shown in Fig. 4 a, the C 1 s band is deconvoluted into several sub-peaks. Specifically, the binding energies at 284.6, 286.1, 286.7, and 287.5 eV under the discharged state correspond to sp2 carbon (benzene rings), C–N (COF linkage), C–O, and C=O bond, respectively. The large percentage of the C–O bond (36.9%) indicates that the RaCOF has undergone a reduction reaction, with the C=O bond transforming into the C–O for metal ion (i.e., Li+) storage [66]. For the higher binding energy regions, the energies at 288.5, 290.2, and 292.9 eV correspond to the PVDF binder [67]. After charging, the C=C bond exhibits the highest sub-peak, followed by the C=O bond with a proportion of 24.8% and a small proportion of the C–O bond at 9.8%. The transformation between the C=O and C–O bonds verifies the reversible ion storage behavior of the quinone carbonyl groups within the RaCOF structure, which is consistent with the in-situ ATR-FTIR result. Moreover, the Li 1 s spectrum in the discharged state showed binding energies at 54.8, 55.8, and 56.6 eV, corresponding to Li–N, Li–S, and Li–O bonds, respectively (Fig. 4b). The substantial content of the Li–O bond further demonstrates that the C=O bonds have been converted to C–O–Li. After charging, the decreased content of the C–O bond implies that most C–O–Li bonds have been reconverted to C=O bonds. Additionally, the fine spectrum of S 2p reveals the sulfur conversion between the discharged and charged states [18]. Apart from the electrolyte and sulfates (with binding energy ranging from 167.4 to 169.4 eV), there were two main chemical environment for the sulfur cathode (Fig. 4c). The binding energy at 162.1 eV corresponds to terminal lithium polysulfides (i.e., Li2S and Li2S2), and the binding energy at 163.9 eV corresponds to sublimed sulfur (i.e., S8). These results indicate that the RaCOF coating layer can not only intercept shuttling sulfur but also facilitate its conversion with the help of the redox-active site. Furthermore, an in-situ XRD test was conducted to study the interaction of the COF layer with sulfur cathodes [26]. As shown in Fig. 4d and 4e, the contour maps of XRD plots correlated with real-time discharge/charge processes were exhibited. For the RaCOF-modified cells (Fig. 4d), intense peaks of sublimed sulfur (α-S8) were initially observed and gradually decreased during the discharge test (from stage A to B), corresponding to the conversion of α-S8 into LiPSs. When the depth of discharge (DOD) reached 55.3%, a broad XRD peak emerged around 26.8°, corresponding to the (111) facet of the Li2S product (JCPDS 023-0369). The characteristic Li2S peak then gradually increased and slowly faded as the test transitioned from discharging to charging (from stage B to E). When the depth of charge (DOC) reached 52.9%, the characteristic peak of Li2S almost disappeared, indicating the transformation from Li2S to soluble polysulfides. Furthermore, the characteristic peaks of β-S8 (JCPDS 071-0137) were monitored at the end of the charge process (from stage E to F), indicating the typical Li–S redox reaction mechanism. In contrast, the cell modified with PhCOF exhibited a delayed emergence peak of Li2S (at the DOD value of 63.3%) (Fig. 4e), indicating a sluggish conversion from α-S8 to the terminal Li2S product. Moreover, a slow conversion process from Li2S to soluble polysulfides was observed with a high DOC value of 74.1%, and less distinct peaks of β-S8 were monitored, implying incomplete sulfur cathode conversion. Therefore, traditional Li–S batteries suffer from three main issues: the shuttling of long-chain LiPSs, sluggish conversion from soluble LiPSs (i.e., Li2S4) to solid Li2S2/Li2S (considered as the capacity-limiting step), and incomplete oxidation of LiPSs, which significantly hinder their stable operation (Fig. 4f). ToF-SIMS and in-situ XRD analyses demonstrated that the polar and porous COF layer can trap LiPSs shuttling and the built-in redox-active moiety of COF can facilitate the conversion from soluble LiPSs to solid Li2S2/Li2S, as well as enhance the oxidation of sulfur species compared with inactive COF-modified cells. Hence, we proposed the upgraded Li–S redox reaction mechanism that illustrated in Fig. 4g. 2.4 Room-temperature test and performance comparison Additionally, comprehensive electrochemical tests were conducted on COF-modified cells. Initially, CV tests revealed the reduction peak around 2.3 V corresponding to the conversion from S8 to soluble polysulfides (i.e., Li2Sn, 4 ≤ n ≤ 8), while the second reduction peak near 2.0 V attributes to the conversion from Li2S4 to solid short-chain polysulfides (i.e., Li2S2/Li2S). As for the oxidation scanning, the peak ranging from 2.3 to 2.6 V corresponds to the reverse oxidation reaction from solid polysulfides back to long-chain polysulfides and eventually to S8. As shown in Fig. 5 a, both PhCOF and RaCOF-modified cells exhibited higher current densities compared to the unmodified cell. The RaCOF-modified cell demonstrated a higher reduction potential (2.35 V vs. Li+/Li) for generating long-chain polysulfides than the PhCOF sample (2.33 V vs. Li+/Li). Moreover, the RaCOF-modified cell exhibited a lower oxidation potential (2.24 V vs. Li+/Li) than the PhCOF sample (2.25 V vs. Li+/Li), indicating the smaller energy barrier for the oxidation of solid Li2S2/Li2S. Furthermore, we conducted four consecutive cycles of CV, and although both RaCOF and PhCOF showed good overlap (except for the first cycle), RaCOF exhibited smaller subsequent polarization compared to the PhCOF sample (Figures S19 and S20). Subsequently, the rate performance of the cells was tested at stepwise currents ranging from 0.1 to 5.0 C. As shown in Fig. 5b, the RaCOF-modified cell achieved capacities of 1847, 1233, 1034, 890, 762, 681, and 627 mAh g−1 under the current rates ranging from 0.1 to 4 C, outperforming both the PhCOF-modified and unmodified cells. Even at the current of 5 C, the RaCOF-modified cell maintained a capacity of 590 mAh g−1 with a minimal polarization voltage of 0.44 V, compared to the PhCOF-modified cell, which had 428 mAh g−1 and a polarization voltage of 0.81 V (Figure S21). Notably, the initial capacity at 0.1 C for RaCOF surpassed the theoretical capacity (1675 mAh g−1), mainly due to the capacity contribution from the redox-active benzoquinone moiety and the capacitive adsorption of Li+ in COF materials. Moreover, the RaCOF-modified cell detected at 0.2 C exhibits higher and more stable cycling (Fig. 5c). Specifically, the RaCOF-modified cell initially delivered 1533 mAh g−1, which sharply decreased to 1380 mAh g−1 by the third cycle and then stabilized at 1032 mAh g−1 by the 100th cycle. The more rapid capacity decay observed in the initial cycles is mainly due to the uneven distribution of sulfur species and a higher concentration of polysulfides resulting from initial electrolyte wetting, which intensifies the shuttle effect. With further cycling, polysulfide distribution becomes more uniform, and a passivation layer gradually forms at the interface, which stabilizes the capacity. In sharp contrast, both the PhCOF-modified and unmodified cells demonstrated lower capacity and faster decay rates. Self-discharge behavior is one of the most challenging issues for practical Li–S batteries [18]. Generally, the concentration of soluble polysulfides reaches its peak when discharging to 2.1 V, which can shuttle to the anode based on the gradient concentration. Consequently, these shuttled polysulfides may react with the lithium anode, consuming the sulfur cathode and thus decreasing the reversible discharge capacity in subsequent cycles. Specifically, the RaCOF-modified cell exhibits 1224 mAh g−1 at the 9th cycle (with a 7-day rest at 2.1 V) and 1175 mAh g−1 at the 10th cycle (Fig. 5d), demonstrating a low self-discharge rate of 4% (equivalent to 49 mAh g−1). After the self-discharge test, the RaCOF cell maintained 1002 mAh g−1 at the 50th cycle. In contrast, the PhCOF sample shows a higher self-discharge rate of 7% (equivalent to 80 mAh g−1), and the unmodified cell displays a significant self-discharge rate of 17.5% (equivalent to 160 mAh g−1) (Figure S22). The excellent anti-self-discharge performance of RaCOF is mainly due to the dual effects of physical blocking from the porous skeleton and chemical trapping from the polar units. Additionally, the prolonged cycling of RaCOF at 5 C was tested, with the RaCOF initially delivering a capacity of 492 mAh g−1 and maintaining 463 mAh g−1 over 500 cycles, showing an outstanding capacity retention of 94.1% (Fig. 5e). The heavy loading of sulfur cathode was tested under conditions of 4.0 mgs cm−2 and a lean electrolyte (electrolyte/sulfur (E/S) ratio controlled at 5.0 μL mgs −1). Specifically, the RaCOF-modified cell initially delivered capacities of 1316, 1129, and 947 mAh g−1 at 0.1, 0.2, and 0.5 C, respectively (Fig. 5f). Even at the high current of 1 C, the cell delivered 785 mAh g−1 with moderate polarization behavior (Fig. 5g), and maintained at 1154 mAh g−1 when the current returning back to 0.1 C. Furthermore, when the cathode loading climbing to 5.0 mgs cm−2, the cell initially delivered 1177 mAh g−1 at 0.1 C after two activation cycles at 0.05 C (Fig. 5h) and preserved a capacity of 964 mAh g−1 (indexing to 4.82 mAh cm−2). This room-temperature performance demonstrates considerable competitiveness among recently reported works (Fig. 5i, Table S1). 2.5 Wide-temperature test and performance comparison Rechargeable batteries often face drastic temperature changes in practical applications, making wide temperature performance one of the most urgent challenges for Li–S batteries to overcome [24–26]. When the working temperature was increased to 30, 40, 50, and 60 ℃, the RaCOF-modified cell showed decreased polarization and coulombic efficiency (Figure S23). Specifically, the RaCOF-modified cell delivered capacities of 1360, 1405, 1434, and 1446 mAh g−1 at 0.5 C across temperatures from 30 to 60 ℃ (Fig. 6 a). Moreover, the cell operated stably at 60 ℃ over 200 cycles (Fig. 6b), initially exhibited 1418 mAh g−1 and decreased to 1060 mAh g−1 at the 100th cycle, finally maintained 870 mAh g−1 at the 200th cycle (Figure S24). The average coulombic efficiency (ACE) during the high-temperature test was 98.2%, indicating minimal polysulfide shuttling. After that, the electrochemical performance under sub-room temperature conditions was studied. As shown in Fig. 6c, the RaCOF cell was tested at 0.5 C under temperatures of 20, 10, 0, and −10 ℃. The cell delivered capacities of 1304, 1174, 1073, and 862 mAh g−1 respectively, and exhibited tolerable polarization behavior (Figure S25). The modified cell also demonstrated stable operation at −10 ℃ over 200 cycles (Fig. 6d), initially exhibited 856 mAh g−1 and maintained a high capacity retention rate of 83.5% (715 mAh g−1) over 200 cycles at 0.5 C (Figure S26). The ACE for the low-temperature test (−10 ℃) was determined to be 99.8%, indicating negligible shuttling behavior, likely due to the tardy migration of polysulfides. Moreover, the high-rate cycling of the RaCOF-modified cell under low-temperature conditions was tested. The RaCOF cell under −10 ℃ initially delivered 730 mAh g−1 at 1 C (Fig. 6e), maintained 605 mAh g−1 (82.8% capacity retention) at the 250th cycle, and gradually decreased to 461 mAh g−1 (63% capacity retention) at the 500th cycle (Figure S27). During low-temperature cycling, the ACE remained above 99.7% for the first 100 cycles, then slightly decreased, maintaining an overall ACE of 99.2%. This performance is derived from the slow diffusion of Li+ and the lower reaction kinetics of polysulfides in the early stages of low-temperature cycling. However, as cycling continues, the concentration of polysulfides increases, and their diffusion kinetics improve, leading to some diffusion behavior and a decrease in coulombic efficiency. Overall, the obtained wide-temperature electrochemical results are comparable to recently reported studies (Fig. 6f, Table S2). 3 Conclusions As a proof-of-concept study, we developed a redox-active COF to simultaneously block polysulfide shuttling and promote their conversion, providing an effective solution for the stable operation of Li–S batteries across a wide temperature range. Our design incorporates a porous RaCOF barrier composed of electrochemically active anthraquinone building blocks, which accelerate the kinetics of polysulfide conversion. The RaCOF exhibits reversible C=O/C-OLi transformations and enhances sulfur redox reactions in ether-based electrolytes. In situ XRD and ToF-SIMS analyses confirm that RaCOF accelerates polysulfide adsorption, enhances the generation of the terminal discharged product (Li2S), and improves the reutilization of the sulfur cathode. Consequently, RaCOF-modified Li–S batteries achieve low self-discharge (4.0% decay rate over a 7-day rest), wide-temperature adaptability (stable operation from −10 to +60 °C), and high-rate cycling stability (94% retention over 500 cycles at 5.0 C). This work provides insights into the rational design of COF structures in temperature-adaptive rechargeable batteries. coredata.dc:description: Covalent organic frameworks (COFs) are promising materials for mitigating polysulfide shuttling in lithium-sulfur (Li–S) batteries, but enhancing their ability to convert polysulfides across a wide temperature range remains a challenge. Herein, we introduce a redox-active COF (RaCOF) that functions as both a physical barrier and a kinetic enhancer to improve the temperature adaptability of Li–S batteries. The RaCOF constructed from redox-active anthraquinone units accelerates polysulfide conversion kinetics through reversible C=O/C-OLi transformations within a voltage range of 1.7 to 2.8 V (vs. Li+/Li), optimizing sulfur redox reactions in ether-based electrolytes. Unlike conventional COFs, RaCOF provides bidentate trapping of polysulfides, increasing binding energy and facilitating more effective polysulfide management. In-situ XRD and ToF-SIMS analyses confirm that RaCOF enhances polysulfide adsorption and promotes the transformation of lithium sulfide (Li2S), leading to better sulfur cathode reutilization. Consequently, RaCOF-modified Li–S batteries demonstrate low self-discharge (4.0% decay over a 7-day rest), excellent wide-temperature performance (stable from −10 to + 60 °C), and high-rate cycling stability (94% capacity retention over 500 cycles at 5.0 C). This work offers valuable insights for designing COF structures aimed at achieving temperature-adaptive performance in rechargeable batteries.
